choiceB: a retiree with significant bone loss

questionText:
A tissue banks is responsible for screening the medical histories of the donors and freeze
the donated bones (T/F)
What could be a risk that is associated with surgical procedure of bone graft?

Due to ethical concerns, all bone graft materials can only come from donors who have
died (T/F)

A medical student is asked by his professor to explain how a bone graft works in a
patient. What should the student say?
choiceA: it provides a framework for growth of fresh and living bone
choiceB: it dissolves into essential compounds like calcium and phosphate
choiceC: it stimulates immune cells to engulf cancerous bone cells
choiceD: it increases blood flow to the implanted area

questionText:
Several different cell types work together to maintain bone integrity, and many evolve
from osteogenic cells. Where are these osteogenic cells typically located?

be a possible reason for this finding?

Bone graft cannot be considered in a patient who needs a large segments of bone that are
more than 6 inches in length (T/F)

After the doctor examines her, a spinal fusion is needed for her healing. What does spinal
fusion entail?
choiceC: relieve pressure on nerve roots of effected area

questionText:
On top of stabilizing fractures, graft material can also regenerate the bone tissue around
implanted devices (T/F)

Certain chronic disease can impede bone growth in patients compared to healthy
individuals, causing them to need bone graft to heal better. What are some examples of

Although nicotine has many adverse health effects in smokers, studies have not shown
that it impedes bone healing. (T/F)

Because of higher autoimmune attack rate in smokers, surgeons typically avoid
performing bone grafts on them because the risks are greater than the benefit. (T/F)

A man receives bone graft in his hip after suffering from a severe car accident. The

heal completely?

A man receives bone graft in his hip after suffering from a severe car accident. The
procedure went smoothly and he feels well. What medications may be prescribed during

Although bone graft alternatives offer low risks of disease infection, they can still be
associated with inflammation in some patients (T/F)
What is an example of graft composite?

shown to be more effective than bone graft (T/F)
Excessive movement is a local factor that can lead to delayed healing or non-union (T/F)
What is not an applications of bone graft technology in dentistry?

choiceA: Stretched skin due to collagen loss

questionText: In the United States, over 900,000 autografts are harvested each year (T/F)

Allograft tissue at bone backs are processed in carefully controlled environments to

choiceB: autografts only contain the patient’s own cells
choiceC: autografts are autoclaved to eliminate microbes
choiceD: there is no substantial difference in rejection risk

questionText:
Allograft can reduce the risk of infection, and it reduces the pain associated with bone
harvesting (T/F)

accident. Multiple fracture sites are found. Why might she not be a good candidate for
autografts?
choiceB: limited amount of bone available for autograft

questionText: What type of graft material is likely to grow faster in the host bone?

compared to fresh-frozen bone allografts (T/F)

most bone banks?

AATB?

A bone bank receives a potential donor’s death after a motor vehicle collision. In order to

be procured?
choiceA: No, because the donor likely has an infectious disease
choiceB: No, because of the time-sensitive nature of procurement

questionText:

Most bone donors are old people who died from natural causes or patients with incurable

choiceA: to kill bacteria in the blood
choiceB: to preserve the red pigments called hemoglobin
choiceC: to increase the oxygen carrying ability of the blood

questionText:
People with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease can still donate blood as long as the blood bank
remove white blood cells from the blood (T/F)
What are some common infectious agents screened at a blood bank?
In Northern India and central Asia, the frequency of which blood type is relatively high?

A patient with Type A blood is suffering blood loss from a vehicle accident. At the
emergency hospital, the doctor accidentally administered Type B blood transfusion. What
symptoms might the patient experience?
choiceA: he will only experience volume loss

questionText:
Blood type is a classification of blood is based on the size and shape of red blood cells
(T/F)

Donors with what kind of medical history would most likely experience adverse
consequences to a transfusion?
choiceB: disease of the blood vessels in the brain, heart failure

questionText:
For patients who have undergone recent surgery, if a transfusion was given at the time of
surgery, donation may be allowed after one year of recovery (T/F)
Which donor below is more likely to feel dizziness and fainting following donation?
choiceB: a young male with morbid obesity

questionText:
In newborn jaundice, a baby has yellow skin and eyes due to a high level of what
substance in the blood?
Which of the infant’s organ primarily process bilirubin to prevent its toxic effects?

Transfusion can improve an infant’s yellow skin, but phototherapy is required if there’s
jaundice with severe symptoms (T/F)
What is the purpose of performing apheresis on whole blood?

choiceB: remove harmful or infectious substances from the blood
choiceC: enrich the blood with vital nutrients and minerals

questionText:
While very useful, apheresis is a time-intensive process that can take several days to
complete (T/F)
How many needles are required to perform apheresis?

Red Cross is the organization that legislate policies on blood transfusions and donor

From 2019 to 2020, many blood drives were canceled at workplaces, colleges and other

After a work accident at a construction site, a 42-year-old man received 1000 cc of blood
product. In 3 hours, he developed fever, chills and rash. A transfusion reaction is
suspected. What is the safest next step of management?

transfusion (T/F)

If a transfusion reaction is suspected, a freshly collected blood sample from the patient
should be returned the blood bank for investigation (T/F)
What populations are more likely to experience acute reaction from blood transfusion?

Young people generate more ABO antibodies; therefore, they are more likely to present
with symptoms from transfusion reaction. (T/F)

Newborns are especially susceptible to transfusion reactions during their first few months
of life due to immature blood cells (T/F)

Some viral infections may cause aplastic anemia. What are some other potential causes?
All Jehovah’s Witnesses believe that it is against God’s will to receive blood (T/F)

If a known Jehovah’s Witness adult patient has already refused to consent to a blood
transfusion on record, what is the best course of action during an emergency?

choiceC: ask the church authority for an exemption

A double red cell donation, as the name suggest, is twice as fast as a normal whole blood
donation (T/F)

In addition to maintaining a healthy blood pressure, plasma also serves a variety of

more tissues (T/F)

nutrients for various microbes. (T/F)

Natural platelets are small pigmented blood cells that help the clotting process by sticking

choiceA: fend off bacterial growth on the cornea

The less fluid movement over corneal cells, the more flexible and elastic the corneal cells
become due to filament production (T/F)

Emulating blinking eyelid and moving tears may improve ophthalmic drug development

Dry eye syndrome is usually an acute problem that resolves with artificial tears in a few
days (T/F)

For some patients with dry eye, what additional element in eye drops may improve
outcome?

Severe dry eye can lead to disabling eye pain and sensitivity to light in worse cases. What
population is at greater risk for dry eye?

To reduce the number of visits to the emergency departments due to keratitis, what can
eye doctors educate their patients about?

The CDC recommends antibiotic-infused contact lenses to reduce the risk of infection
and inflammation of the cornea (T/F)

A college student scheduled an appointment at the university student clinic during finals
week. His chief complaint is eye pain. He has been studying and napping in the library

In 3D printing with bioink, what is used to control the pattern of collagen fibrils?

Compared to other alternatives, 3D-peinted cornea has the potential to achieve

One of the common procedures is a corneal transplant. What is this also known as?

elect a surgical procedure (T/F)

In corneal transplant, how is the donor tissue usually secured in the patient’s eye?

After a corneal procedure, the doctor tells the patient that it may take several months to a
year for healing to take place. Why does corneal transplant heals relatively slowly
compared to many other types of tissues?

Usually, a suture is only used in penetrating keratoplasty but not in lamellar keratoplasty

A 63-year-old patient has suffered from blurry vision for several years. Upon
examination, the doctor told him that the innermost layer of his cornea is defective. What
procedure is appropriate for him?
Why is an air bubble left in place under the cornea in a keratoplasty procedure?
Which of the following is not a function served by the epithelium of the cornea?

The epithelium is the outermost layer of the cornea consisting of a single cell layer that
allow for diffusion nutrients (T/F)

Why is surgery not always required to replace the epithelial layer of the cornea if it is
only slightly scratched?

The cornea consists of multiple layers of tissue with different thickness. What is the only
layer that contain blood vessels?

The stroma has approximately 200 layers of collagen tissue, which gives the cornea its
strength and elasticity. However, the stroma is mostly made up of water. (T/F)

Under the microscope, the stroma of the cornea can be seen as arranged collagen fibers
along with sparsely distributed keratocytes. What is the function of these keratocytes?

dysfunction of which corneal layer may have contributed to this fluid accumulation?

Due to its proximity to nutrient supply and basal stem cells, the endothelium of the
cornea has the greatest regenerative ability (T/F)
How does the endothelium maintain fluid balance in the cornea to maintain transparency?

When possible, why is endothelial keratoplasty performed compared to a penetrating
keratoplasty?
Where is the Descemet's membrane found in the human eye?

least 2300 cells/mm2 (T/F)

A legally blind patient requires a Descemet's Stripping endothelium keratoplasty
(DSEK). He is placed in the waitlist of a local eye bank. Where do endothelial cell in eye

In DSEK, where is a thin disc containing healthy endothelium cells inserted?

The minimal incision to insert healthy cells into the cornea, in a DSEK procedure, is
9mm. (T/F)
Why do surgeons tend to harvest DMEK tissue from eyes above 50 years of age only?
choiceA: Descemet's membrane has better cell count in older donors
choiceB: Descemet's membrane is too firmly attached in younger donors
choiceC: Descemet's membrane from younger donors causes tissue rejection
choiceD: Descemet's membrane is thicker in older donors

questionText: Compared to DSEK, what is a greater risk of performing DMEK?
DSEK has better visual outcomes in terms of contrast visual acuity than DMEK (T/F)

discovered in 2013?

PDEK is a newer procedure with lower cell loss during donor tissue preparation than
DMEK (T/F)

penetrating keratoplasty?

Women on birth control pills have a higher likelihood of developing hepatic adenoma

choiceB: cell division gets out of control

questionText:
Aflatoxin can be found in certain type of fungus that spreads through spored. How does
aflatoxin play a role in liver cancer?

Viruses may cause certain cancers. One way is by inserting its genes into a liver cell's
DNA, where it may turn on the cell's oncogenes (T/F)
Which of the following demographic has the highest increase in death from liver cancer?

What are some actionable targets that the government can invests in to decrease death
rate associated with liver cancer?

Study has shown that the risk of dying from liver cancer quadruples for those without a
college degree compared to those with one (T/F)

A man recently noticed fullness in his right upper abdomen. He proceeds to visit the
doctor and was subsequently diagnosed with liver cancer. What other symptoms is he
likely experiencing?

Why might the detection of liver cancer be detected later than some of the other types of
cancer?
choiceA: liver cancer tends to resolve by itself
choiceB: signs and symptoms appear at later stage
choiceC: liver cancer tends to affect healthy, young adults

questionText:
Liver cancer can cause constipation indirectly by producing hormone that increases
calcium level (T/F)

A rise in alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) in a patient can indicate a possibility of liver cancer, but
it is not the definitive indicator. What other causes could increase AFP??

After extensive treatment, a rise in AFP in a patient who was diagnosed with liver cancer
can mean that the cancer is recurring (T/F)
Besides AFP, what other biological markers can be used to detect liver cancer?
Second cancer is also called recurring cancer. The two often share the same cause (T/F)

People who has a history of liver cancer may have an increased risk of developing what
other types of cancer?
According to the American Cancer Society, what types of cancer can be screened?

A secondary liver cancer may start from the stomach or colon, but not the liver itself
(T/F)
Which of the following treatment can guarantee complete eradication of cancer cells?
In a patient with liver cancer, what organ function may be impared?

Besides tumor biopsy, there may also be specific markers in the bloodstream that help
doctors diagnose liver cancer (T/F)
What is the characteristic of a resectable liver cancer?

Liver cancer can be respectable or unresectable. Unresectable cancers means that cancer
that have already spread to lymph nodes or distant sites. (T/F)

While the waitlist for liver transplant may be long, who could be good candidates for a
liver transplant?
choiceA: a patient with extensive liver cirrhosis
choiceB: a patient with most alcohol consumption
choiceC: a patient of higher economic status

questionText: What could be considered as a treatment for patients who cannot tolerate drug therapy?

Partial hepatectomy can be considered for people with good liver function. It may not
benefit those who are too sick for surgery and who have multiple tumors (T/F)
What is an initial test to determine if a liver cancer can be removed surgically?
What is a potential benefit of performing liver transplant compared to liver resection?

Compared to liver resection, ablation is treatment that destroys liver tumors without
removing them. What kinds of tumor can be good candidates?
General anesthesia is not required for ablation because it is done without surgery. (T/F)
What imaging is commonly used to help guide ablation procedures?

Embolization can be used to target liver tumor supplied by the hepatic artery, while sparing
the rest of the liver that gets oxygen from the portal vein (T/F)
Why is embolization used to remove certain tumors, as opposed to ablation?

Before receiving embolization for his stage 2 tumor, a patient is informed by the doctor
regarding potential side effects. What are some potential side effects?

Large liver tumors can sometimes be treated with embolization. In this procedure, what is
inserted into an artery in the inner thigh through a small cut?

Besides blocking the blood supply to the liver cancer, embolization can also be used in
conjunction with what other techniques?

Due to the high risk of radioactive toxicity, patients receiving embolization should be
receiving radiation therapy (T/F)

In external beam radiation therapy, small particles with radioactivity is applied to the skin
and absorbed by the blood stream (T/F)

Despite effecting only local tumors, radiation therapy can carry the risks of diarrhea,
fatigue, and loss of appetite. Patients often lose weight during treatment (T/F)

Which technique allow radioactive substances to enter into the hepatic artery, thereby
killing liver cancer?

As an aggressive treatment. chemo drugs tend to have the best long-term patient outcome
because it completely eradicates systemic cancer cells, (T/F)

Permanent cells that divide slowly, such as nerve cells, are especially prone to be damaged
by chemo drugs, causing significant pain symptoms during therapy (T/F)

A late-stage liver cancer patient has been receiving chemo therapy for 4 weeks. He has
lost most of his hair and exhibited many other common side effects. Which of the
following is not a common side effect from chemotherapy?
Different chemotherapy drugs may have different routs of administration, such as

Due to the localized effect of hepatic artery infusion, patients are spared from common
side effects such as nausea and vomiting (T/F)

A patient with liver cancer asks about the duration of his chemo treatment, and learns that
he will have several weeks of drugless period in between treatments. Why is rest period
programmed into cycles of chemotherapy?
choiceA: for the drug to exert its effect
choiceB: for patient to recover from drug effects
choiceC: for the doctor to take a break

questionText:
Increased kinase activity can inhibit cancer growth because kinases stop the cell cycle
(T/F)

Targeted drugs have different functions from chemotherapy drugs and often have different
side effects. What is a mechanism used by target therapy to prevent cancer growth?
What category of cancer drug does man-made antibodies fall into?

Patient should not receive additional chemotherapy after their treatment is over because of
the significant toxic side effects that come with it (T/F)

A man just went through 2 months of intense chemotherapy, and he has been free of liver
cancer biomarkers for several weeks. However, he is recommended to schedule regular
follow-ups. What is the purpose for these follow-ups?
choiceB: screen for spread to distant sites

questionText:
What diagnostic modality may the doctor use to check for cancer recurrence after treatment
is completed?

A secondary liver cancer may start from the stomach or colon, but not the liver itself
(T/F)
Which of the following treatment can guarantee complete eradication of cancer cells?
In a patient with liver cancer, what organ function may be impared?

Besides tumor biopsy, there may also be specific markers in the bloodstream that help
doctors diagnose liver cancer (T/F)
What is the characteristic of a resectable liver cancer?

The small intestine contains many layers, and it is made up of both the colon and rectum
(T/F)

A patient is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. In the clinic, he appears pale and tired. Lab
results show low blood count. How can colorectal cancer cause low red blood sells over
time if it is not treated?
choiceA: it prevents cell formation in the bone marrow
choiceB: cancer cells produce toxins that destructs blood cells

questionText:
Screening for colorectal cancer has the potential to save lives. What is an effective
screening method?

Colorectal cancer can progress to different stages. What does the stage of a tumor depend
on?

if colorectal cancer has spread to multiple body organs, a systemic therapy is more suited
for treatment (T/F)

While cancers can originate from different sites in the body, what is a characteristic they
share in common?

A biology student is given several images of biopsy samples from a deceased patient.
What kind of image could reveal that the patient died from cancer?
choiceD: cell swelling and loss of membrane

questionText:
Chemotherapy and surgery are often used together to treat cancer, with greater effect than
used alone (T/F)

Most polyp types can be identified by the gastroenterologist by visual inspection without
microscope to determine if they are cancerous (T/F)

A 50-year-old man underwent his first colonoscopy, from which a 1-cm polyp is found
and dissected. What type of tumor could indicate potential pre-cancerous condition?

A physician identifies a polyp in a patient, but he cannot tell the grading of the tumor.
What should he do next?
choiceA: leave it to avoid unnecessary harm
choiceC: follow up with ultrasound in 2 months

questionText:
Staging describes the process of determining if the underlying cells of a tumor grow in an
orderly structure or not (T/F)

The TNM system is central to staging various types of cancer. Which pairing below match
what it stands for correctly?
choiceA: T: tumor shape | N: nodularity | M: morphology
choiceB: T: tumor size | N: lymph node involvement | M: morphology
choiceC: T: tumor size | N: nodularity | M: metastasis
choiceD: T: tumor size | N: lymph node involvement | M: metastasis

questionText:
Out of the TNM system, Tumor size is the most indicative factor to determine worst
prognostic outcome of the cancer (T/F)

Colonoscopy is a procedure that identifies suspicious polyps and remove a segment of the
colon or rectum (T/F)

What condition should the colon be in as the patient gets ready for surgery or
colonoscopy?

A surgeon recommends total colectomy to a patient with stage 3 colorectal cancer. What
does this procedure entail?
choiceA: removal of the proximal colon alone

questionText:
Both systemic and regional chemotherapy approaches entail infusing drugs into the blood
(T/F)

An oncologist recommends a patient with early-stage cancer to receive regional
chemotherapy after his surgery. How does regional chemotherapy decrease drug toxicity?
choiceB: lower the concentration of the drug dose
choiceC: reduce drug reaching the rest of the body

questionText:
Chemotherapy drugs attack cells that are dividing quickly, which causes common side
effects such as:

Lynch syndrome is a common hereditary colorectal cancer syndrome with a genetic defect
in which gene?

Patients with hereditary Lynch syndrome tend to develop when people reach advanced age
because of weakened cell regulation (T/F)
Besides colorectal cancer, what other organs may be effected by Lynch syndrome?

The colon is a muscular tube about 5 feet long, made up of several compartments. Which
of the following is not a component of the colon?
What does the proximal colon consist of?

The colon mostly excretes excessive water and salt into the partially processed food matter
to create the soft fecal texture (T/F)

Although everyone could get colorectal cancer, it happens at different rates across racial
and ethnic groups. What are some underlying factors?

Which of the following demographic groups have the highest colorectal cancer risks in
the world?

Although colorectal cancer rates are higher in blacks than non-Hispanic whites, death
rates are lower in blacks due to genetic protection (T/F)

Men with genetic mutation in SMAD7 are found to have a higher risk of colorectal
cancer, when they measure a higher BMI (T/F)

Which gender sees in higher increase in risk of getting colorectal cancer due to increase
in BMI?

What does obesity act like for women with a high-risk genetic makeup for colorectal
cancer?

All previous studies have conclusively shown that higher vitamin D in the blood
decreases the risk for colorectal cancer (T/F)

Based on the current study, what is the risks for colorectal cancer associated with vitamin
D deficiency compared to normal levels?

A patient is told that he has vitamin D deficiency in his health maintenance visit. He asks
how he can replenish his levels. What are some sources of vitamin D?

The small intestine contains many layers, and it is made up of both the colon and rectum
(T/F)

A patient is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. In the clinic, he appears pale and tired. Lab
results show low blood count. How can colorectal cancer cause low red blood sells over
time if it is not treated?
choiceA: it prevents cell formation in the bone marrow
choiceB: cancer cells produce toxins that destructs blood cells

questionText:
Screening for colorectal cancer has the potential to save lives. What is an effective
screening method?

Colorectal cancer can progress to different stages. What does the stage of a tumor depend
on?

if colorectal cancer has spread to multiple body organs, a systemic therapy is more suited
for treatment (T/F)
Why has the death rate from colorectal cancer been decreasing in the US?

Screening allows doctors to catch colorectal cancer early in the form of polyps. What is a
typical time frame it takes for a poly to become cancerous?

Most Americans who fit the criteria to get tested for colorectal cancer already receives
regular screening (T/F)

Every country has a different guideline regarding colorectal cancer screening. What is the
recommended age put forth by the American Cancer Society?

Earlier screening is recommended for people at higher risk of colorectal cancer. Which of
the following constitutes higher risk?

People over the age of 75 should always receive cancer screening more regularly because
of higher risks at advanced age (T/F)

When given different options for colorectal cancer screening, what would be a good
option for someone who does not want invasive procedures?
choiceD: more than one answer is correct

questionText:
Both FIT and gFOBT look for occult blood in the patient’s stool. What is one difference
in preparing for the test?

DNA screening, like FIT and gFOBT, analyzes the patient’s stool and is done once a year
(T/F)

When given different options for colorectal cancer screening, what would be a good
option for someone who does not want to get screened very frequently?

Colonoscopy is generally a safe but carry a small risk of puncturing the wall of the colon
or rectum, causing blood loss (T/F)

What makes some people opt for stool-based screening compared to colonoscopy
screening?
What is the difference between CT scan and regular x-ray?
choiceA: CT scan uses both gamma and alpha rays
choiceB: CT scan is cheaper to obtain
choiceC: CT scan takes multiple pictures around the patient
choiceD: CT scan requires more bowel preparation

questionText:
If CT scan shows possible tumor, then the patient also needs a follow-up colonoscopy to
remove the polyps (T/F)

Medicare generally covers both stool-based tests and CT scan, but not colonoscopy for
preventative cancer screening. Therefore, patients are less likely to opt for colonoscopy
(T/F)

In order to fully empty the stomach before colonoscopy, patients must fast for 3 days
before the procedure (T/F)

A 50-year-old female is due for her first colonoscopy in a week. What is likely given to
her to help make her bowels clean and empty?

Vegan patients do not have any diet restrictions before colonoscopy because the fiber-
rich foods are beneficial to colon visualization (T/F)

A 45-year-old man disclosed to his doctor that his parents passed away from colorectal
cancer in their 50’s. When recommending screening methods, which one is not
appropriate for him?

What are some of the factors patients have to factor in when choosing the screening
method for colorectal screening?

Providers should only recommend colonoscopy screening to all patients because that is
the most effective method (T/F)

Above the age of 45, patients can choose any kind of colorectal screening method they
want because the Affordable Care Act mandates universal coverage and no out-of-pocket
cost (T/F)

Despite insurance coverage, what situations may require patients to pay out-of-pocket
for colorectal screening?
choiceB: certain screening methods like CT scan

questionText:
What does the patient need to pay when doctors remove polyps after they are detected in
screening?

A couple in their 50’s recently retired and have medical insurance through Medicare.
Their son recently turned 25. Can their son be covered under their plan?
choiceC: depends on if he’s in graduate school

questionText:
Young adults who are eligible for their parents’ insurance got the same care as before the
ACA allowed them to be covered. This is because young adults are usually healthy to
begin with (T/F)

Young adults benefit from the ACA policy allowing them to stay under their parent’s
insurance because
choiceC: it gives them peace of mind

questionText:
What legislative change has caused an increase in colorectal cancer screening among
people ages 45 to 49?

New guidelines in 2018 likely made doctors and patients more aware of the importance
of colorectal cancer screening, especially in younger patients (T/F)
What is the biggest reason to update the guideline for colorectal screening?
choiceB: insurance companies can attract more patients

questionText:
The small intestine contains many layers, and it is made up of both the colon and rectum
(T/F)

results show low blood count. How can colorectal cancer cause low red blood sells over
time if it is not treated?
choiceA: it prevents cell formation in the bone marrow
choiceB: cancer cells produce toxins that destructs blood cells
